children.name: news that people tell each other
news a2
children.definition: news information about something that has happened recently :
examples: i hope to have some good news for you soon.
sb’s newswhat someone has been doing recently
sit down and tell me all your news.
news that
we are delighted at the news that our daughter is expecting a baby.
news on
what’s the latest news on your university application?
news of/about
everyone is shocked by the news of the arrests.
good newshe’s feeling much better, so that’s good news.
great/wonderful newsthey're getting married? that's wonderful news!
welcome news(= good news that makes you happy )the lower interest rates will be welcome news to home owners.
bad news‘i’m afraid i have bad news,’ said jackson.|have you heard the terrible news about simon?
terrible news(= very bad )
the latest newsmom sent a letter with all the latest news.
old news(= news that you have already heard )she wasn’t surprised; it was old news to her.
important newsi've got some important news to tell you.
the big newsinformal(= an important piece of news )the big news is that polly and richard are going to get married.
have some news (for sb)i could tell by his face that he had some news.
tell sb the newsjack called him to tell him the good news.
break the news (to sb)(= tell someone some bad news )two policemen came to the door to break the news about her husband.
hear (the/my etc) news(= tell a lot of people the news )after she had the baby, her husband made phone calls to spread the happy news.
hear the news(= hear about something that has happened )she was really upset when she heard the news.
welcome the newsformal(= say that you are pleased about some news )environmental groups welcomed the news that the area would be protected.
greet the news with surprise/delight etcformal(= react to the news in a particular way )fans greeted the news of the victory with a loud cheer.
news spreads(= a lot of people find out the news from other people )news spreads fast in a small town.
a piece of news(alsoa bit of newsbritish english)leo thought about this piece of news carefully.
the good news is …/the bad news is ...(= used to introduce a piece of good and bad news )the good news is that most stores have the game in stock; the bad news is that it's not cheap.

children.name: the latest x
children.definition: the latestspokenthe most recent news:tin mới nhất
examples: have you heard the latest? phil’s going out with judy!
the latest about/on
oh, i haven’t told you the latest about my car!
what’s the latest on the election?

children.name: developments b2
children.definition: developments the most recent changes in an important situation - used especially in news programmes on television or radio:diễn biến
examples: the president said today that he was watching developments in asia with great interest.
there are no new developments to report at this stage.
further developmentsmore developments
we’ll be keeping you informed of any further developments throughout the day.

children.name: press conference x
children.definition: press conference a meeting held by a person or group at which they answer questions from people who write or present news reports : cuộc họp báo
examples: hold a press conference
the green party held a press conference the next day.

children.name: news conference x
children.definition: news conference a meeting at which someone, especially someone famous or important, speaks to people who work for newspapers or news programmes: cuộc họp báo
examples: the chairman told a news conference that some members of staff would lose their jobs.
shecalleda news conference to give her side of the story.
at/in a news conference
at a news conference yesterday, the two men described their ordeal.

children.name: news in newspapers or news programmes
news a2
children.definition: newsevents that are reported in newspapers or in news programmes: tin tức
examples: a late evening news broadcast
a news and current affairs programme
here’s the sports news from jane murray.
thelatest newsfrom the olympic stadium
news is coming in about an oil spill in the south atlantic.
news about/on/of
news on the latest developments in the talks
the paper was full of news about the peace negotiations.
news that
several evening papers carried the news that a cabinet minister was about to resign.
local/regional/national/international news
we deal mainly with local news.
in the newsreported about on television, radio, in newspapers etc trên báo
she’s been in the news a lot recently.
hong kong is in the news this morning.
his resignationwas front page news(= was important news).
news story/report/item etc
never before has a news story triggered such sensational sales of the newspaper.
we’ve got thenews headlinescoming up at half past twelve.

children.name: the headlines b1
children.definition: the headlinesthe important points of the news, printed in big letters on the front page of a newspaper or read at the beginning of a news broadcast: những tin chính
examples: the eight o'clock headlines
i just have time to glance at the headlines before i leave for work.
this is the six o'clock news. first, the headlines ...

children.name: special report x
children.definition: special report/ newsflashespecially uk/newsbulletinus  a piece of news that is so important that it is broadcast immediately, often in the middle of another programme: tin khẩn
examples: we interrupt this programme to bring you a newsflash.
there were special reports about the accident on all the networks.
all the shows started late because of the news bulletin about the bombing.

children.name: update b2
children.definition: update/ news update a broadcast report of the most recent news about sth: cập nhật/cập nhật tin tức
examples: we will continue to bring you news updates throughout the day.
update/news update on
the latest update on the rescue effort

children.name: top story b2
children.definition: top story/ lead story us the most important piece of news that is reported at the beginning of a news broadcast: tin chính, tin nổi bật
examples: tonight’s top story: unemployment is at a 20 year low.

children.name: report b1
children.definition: report a piece of writing in a newspaper about sth that is happening, or part of a news programme:
examples: we’re getting reports from the scene of the fighting that 12 hostages have been killed.
a news/weather/newspaper etc report
according to recent news reports , two of the victims are americans.
newspaper reports say woods is ‘delighted’ with his success.
we’ll be giving you further news and weather reports every hour throughout the day
report about/on/of/from
newspaper reports on the war
media reports of the food shortages

children.name: story b2
children.definition: story a report in a newspaper or news programme about a recent event or sth that is interesting to the public,especially one that is not very serious or reliable: bài báo, câu truyện
examples: you can’t always believe what you read in newspaper stories.
a front-page story
story about/on
there have been a lot of stories in the papers recently about contaminated food.
a headline-grabbing story
a big story(= a report about something important )he had promised the newspaper a big story on a major celebrity.
the lead/top story(= the most important story in a newspaper or news programme )the floods were the lead story on the news that evening.
a front-page storythe times published a front-page story about the scandal.
a cover story(= the main story in a magazine, mentioned on the cover )hello magazine did a cover story on her last year.
do a story(= write and then print or broadcast it )i went to iraq to do a story on the war.
print/publish a storythe news of the world decided not to print the story.
run a story(= print it or broadcast it )there wasn't enough definite information to run the story.
cover a story(= report on it )her family complained about the way that journalists had covered the story.
break a story(= report on it for the first time )the daily mail was the paper which broke the story.
leak a story(= secretly tell a reporter about it )we may never know who leaked the story to the press.
a story breaks(= it is reported for the first time )i still remember the shock when that story broke.

children.name: item b2
children.definition: item a short report that is part of a news programme or newspaper, magazine etc: mục tin, mẩu tin,
examples: the next item will be of special interest to viewers who are dog-owners.
news item
the news item announcing the verdict was much smaller than the item that announced his arrest.
item on/about
there’s an item about the robbery on page seven.
i turned the page, and saw a small item about muhammad ali

children.name: scoop x
children.definition: scoop an important or exciting news story that is printed in one newspaper or shown on one television station before any of the others know about it : tin xốt dẻo
examples: it was his first major scoop and he promised not to reveal the source of his information.
the paper managed to secure a major scoop and broke the scandal to the world.
a journalist looking for a scoop

children.name: exclusive x
children.definition: exclusive an important or surprising piece of news that is printed in only one newspaper or broadcast by only one news programme, especially because sb has let them use the information before anyone else: tin độc quyền
examples: a new york post exclusive about the kennedy marriage
michael jackson has promised the network an exclusive.
we have exclusives that you won’t find on other networks.
world exclusivesth that has never been reported anywhere before
the newspaper has a reputation for good reporting and world exclusives.
exclusive[attri] độc quyền
at the end of the programme we have an exclusive interview with senator goldwater.

children.name: run c1
children.definition: run to print sth in a newspaper or magazine, or broadcast sth on television :
examples: the company is running a series of advertisements in national newspapers.
channel 4 is running a series on the unfairness of the legal system.
run a storyif a newspaper or news programmeruns a story,it reports a particular event, especially sth that people did not previously know about:đưa tin
the editor decided not to run the story until all the facts were known.
usa today did not run the story until ashe had made his announcement.
all the newspapers ran (= printed) stories about the new peace talks.
a local tv station ran her story.
run[i] c1 if a program runs on television, it is shown. if a story runs in a newspaper or magazine, it is printed : được đưa tin
the series ran for 20 episodes and was extremely popular.
conan doyle’s stories ran in ‘the strand’ magazine.

children.name: report b1
children.definition: report to give people information about recent events, especially in newspapers and on television and radio : đưa tin
examples: this is gavin williams, reporting from the united nations in new york.
we aim to report the news as fairly as possible.
the incident was widely reported in the national press.
report on
the times sent her to bangladesh to report on the floods.
report that
journalists in cairo reported that seven people had been shot.
report doing sth
witnesses reported seeing three people flee the scene.
be reported to be/have done sthreported in a newspaper or news programme
he was reliably reported to be drunk at the white house reception.
she is reported to have thrown a glass of wine at her former boss.

children.name: carry x
children.definition: carry(of a newspaper or radio or television broadcast) to contain particular information: đưa tin
examples: this morning's newspapers all carry the same story on their front page.

children.name: cover c1
children.definition: cover to report the details of an event or a series of events for a newspaper or news programme: đưa tin
examples: he was sent to northern ireland to cover the peace talks.
a magazine covering women’s issues
she's covering the american election for bbc television.

children.name: be in the news b1
children.definition: be in the news sth or sb that is in the news is being written about in newspapers or talked about on television, radio etc: được đưa tin
examples: football teams like to make sure their star players are constantly in the news.
at that time, events in chile were very much in the news.

children.name: make the news a2
children.definition: make the news/make news to be considered important enough to be reported in a newspaper or news programme: lên báo
examples: twenty years ago, environmental issues rarely made the news.
the hoax made national news, and people were talking about it for weeks afterwards.
you made the news recently when you rescued a young boy from drowning -- can you tell us a bit about that?
twenty years ago environmental issues rarely made the news

children.name: hit the headlines b1
children.definition: hit/make/grab the headlines if sth hits, makes, or grabs the headlines, it suddenly starts to be reported in all the main stories in newspapers or on television or radio:
examples: he grabbed the headlines last year when he became the first man to win three grand prix races in a row.
phil andrews again hit the headlines by scoring three goals in last night’s game.
larson’s handling of the case made national headlines last year.

children.name: desk x
children.definition: desk an office that deals with a particular subject, especially in newspapers or television : tòa soạn
examples: the news/sports desk

children.name: press gallery x
children.definition: press gallery in a parliament or other place where laws are made, the upper part of a room where reporters sit to watch what is happening below : khu vực dành cho báo chí

children.name: newsroom x
children.definition: newsroom the office in a newspaper or broadcasting company where news is received and news reports are written : phòng biên tập tin tức

children.name: silly season x
children.definition: silly season
examples: the silly seasonuk informala period in the summer when newspapers print stories that are not very serious because there is not much political news : giai đoạn báo chí thiếu tin, đăng chuyện dớ dẩn

children.name: press release x
children.definition: press release a public statement given to the press to publish if they wish : thông cáo báo chí

children.name: coverage c1
children.definition: coverage the way an event or subject is reported in the news, especially how much space or time is given to reporting it: đưa tin, phủ tin
examples: too much coverage is given to sport on tv and not enough to political issues.
what did you think of the bbc's election coverage?
coverage of
coverage of the greek elections
media/television/press etc coverage
the aids conference received extensive media coverage.
leach had no difficulty getting press coverage for his stunts.

children.name: newsworthy x
children.definition: newsworthy important or interesting enough to be reported in newspapers, on the radio, or on television :
examples: nothing newsworthy ever happens around here. it's so boring.
newsworthy events
